title: Wrote multi threaded program in c++

blocks.text: Yupp, made multiple threads out of the main thread in the PDC software. Well the solution emerged out the very fundamental requirement of the PDC to connect with multiple PMUs at the same time. Since the program runs an infinite loop to accept data from the PMU continuously, you cannot process anything else. This was the major issue was that we could not run execute the sendCloseCommand function and stop the communication on our command. Thus implemented a 3 thread program that accepts data from three pmu and receives user commands on the main thread.
I was super excited while writing code for this part I didn't want to leave the lab even though I had a class at 2PM üòÅ

title: Finally there‚Äôs motion in the project

blocks.text: After commiting plenty of rookie mistakes we finally managed to establish a tcp connection with the phase measurement unit and received its config files.

In the beginning we were thinking that the PMU is a client and it is sending out requests to connect to server to send data, I know it sounds stupid now but we were not given any port that should have suggested us the alternate. Till yesterday we were thinking okay now that it is a server, after connecting to it why the hell is it not sending any data. Finally today while going through the documentation of IEEE C37.118 protocol I came to understand the basic flaw in our approach.

For any communication to start be whatever the protocol there should be a command frame sent by the client to initiate the conversation. I‚Äôve read it in the course on IOT but boy am I not stupid enough to ignore it while implementing and waste timeüò≠. Finally sent a demo command frame according to the docs and voilla we had the gibberish of a config response. Have to decode that piece tomorrow and then we‚Äôll start receiving the phase data.

P2390; medium; 12:42, Following are some notes : It gave TLE in the first try.

The reason why using ans.push_back(st.top()) and reversing the string before returning it works fine, while using ans = st.top() + ans results in TLE, is because the + operator for strings is an expensive operation.

When you use ans = st.top() + ans, for every iteration of the while loop, you are creating a new string by concatenating the current character with the existing string. This new string is then assigned to the ans variable. As the size of the string increases, this operation becomes increasingly expensive, resulting in a TLE for larger inputs.

Sockets are like pointers but for traversing networks. When you start a socket you are returned an integer that you can use to start communication between a server and client.
There are two types of sockets
Socket stream - meant for reliable connections and data integrity. Protocols used are TCP/IP (Transmission control protocol)
Datagram socket - meant for speedy and unreliable connections, used in cases where some data loss is acceptable. Protocol used is UDP(user datagram protocol).

Retrieving the data was the easy part just create a integration on the dev page and put in the your client secret in the getting started code. The real headache was formatting the data of this page. Cheers to the new beginning.

In January, I began drafting this article, and now, in July 2023, I realize I've been delaying its completion for quite some time. However, it's important to clarify that my procrastination wasn't centered around the article itself. Instead, it was due to the limited time I had available to address minor bugs in the Preact.js framework.

Speaking about the website, it operates on the Javascript library that I have developed. It functions as a single-page application with frontend hash routing, altering the URL with different hashes corresponding to various pages. When I deploy the website on a free-tier Platform as a Service (PaaS), it restricts direct access to other routes, making only the default route accessible through URL search and as I don‚Äôt have root access to these servers I had to opt for hash routing.

Not having an easy access to reliable servers for free meant no database and dynamic content on the website, to solve this I had to come up with some innovative solution to have a database that was convenient to update and tagged along with an API. I used google sheets for the projects and books I‚Äôve read page. The data I maintain on the sheet is then hardcoded into the website repository using a Node.js-based automation script i wrote called gitcron. The script commits the changes in sheet on my behalf everytime I start my laptop.
Google sheets wasn‚Äôt a good choice for a CMS for blogposts and learning in public updates, So I chose Notion for this and hooked it up with the same script to update the website content.
Flow of the Website
You visit any domain pointing to this website; currently, it's https://arpitverma.vercel.app
The remote server responds with an index.html and some JavaScript files that get stored in your browser's session storage.
Now according to the route you are on in the website corresponding content is fetched from the stored javascript files.
These javascript files place the stored html into the virtual-dom element in the index.html
The logic and dynamic aspects of the page are implemented separately. As JavaScript stored in session storage cannot perform logic functions, it's used solely to call upon variables.
For the logic part, when a page is called, a corresponding logic script is injected in the index.html.
